"Two stars, fair enough. Motel 6, upgraded to here, but only by one. Bathroom, needs work. Deep cleaning, once in a while, and we're talking a full star more. Rooms, big, balcony, nice. Pool, hot tub, good, but clear out the debris, you know? Service, friendly, helpful. Breakfast, fine. Clean up, Windemere, and you're close."

"Ate at this joint years back, inside the Mirage. Good grub, we thought. Recently, though, it was piss poor. Server didn't know squat about the soup du jour. Nutty broad, too. Made us feel rushed. Food? Shit, it was cold. Sent it back. Prices? Outta whack for the crap they serve. Too many better spots in Vegas. Won't be comin' back."
"Food's good, but service is a bust. Last time, waited 30 minutes, not a single server in sight. Left and hit up another joint. Now, we just call in for wings and grab 'em to go."

"Ay, 'twas a disappointment indeed,
For one accustomed to the finest feed,
In New York's steakhouses, where the beef doth reign,
This place did falter, and my hopes were vain.

With a party of ten, we didst sit down,
To partake in their midday repast, profound.
The menu, full of promise, didst delight,
But alas, my steak, it was not quite right.

Overcooked, it was, and lacking grace,
A sorry sight, upon my plate's face.
And where, oh where, didst the porterhouse steaks go?
I searched the menu, but they didst not show.

The wine, a solace, yet a costly affair,
Even in Vegas, where riches do pour.
So, in conclusion, this place didst not win,
My heart, nor stomach, with its culinary sin."

"Ew. Flavorless canned mushrooms and frozen spinach in my omelet. No seasoning, just a big sloppy mess. Took forever to take our order, much less get it to us. Hash browns were okay, but that's about it. Don't understand the high reviews."

"A single bad attitude can ruin a good experience. That's what happened at 360 Physical Therapy. I was set to give them a great review, but their strict cancellation policy and a disagreement over a missed appointment led to a battle with their billing manager. Despite being a responsible customer, always on time and paying upfront, they wouldn't budge. It's too bad, because I liked my therapist and felt well cared for. But their inflexibility turned a positive experience sour. It's a shame, as I would have returned and recommended them to others. Instead, I'll think twice before going back."
"Place was a dump, real sketchy. Rented some skates, moldy as hell. Only rink in Madison, so not like we had choices. Kids didn't seem to care, still had fun. We dealt with it."

"Hark! I didst recent visit Frank and Lupes,
Where food was plentiful and most delectable,
But alas! Service didst leave much to be desired,
For our waiter didst not come to our table,
And we didst have to journey to the bar,
To fetch our own drinks, which didst seem quite odd.

And at the end of dinner, my companion didst rise,
To use the restroom, leaving me alone,
And lo! Our waiter didst approach me then,
Asking if I didst await to be seated,
As if he hadst not attended me for nigh on two hours,
A strange and curious thing, indeed!"

"The MarchÃ© Bonsecours, a beautiful building, sure. But that's where my admiration ends. Inside, it's all too polished, catering to rich tourists only. They claim to showcase local artists, but it all blends together and costs a pretty penny. Go for a visit, but don't expect to be impressed by the architecture."

"Been here twice. First time, liked the menu, had lunch. Food was good, standard bar fare. Service was decent, not too busy. Found out they got UFC fights, so went back for that. Fight night, they hit us with a $10 cover charge. What the hell? Everywhere else in EV, it's five bucks. Already there, so we stayed. Waitress asks for credit card or ID as security. Are you kidding me? We're a couple of forty-somethings. You think we're gonna dine-and-dash? Reluctantly gave her my card. Fights started, but not all the TVs were tuned in. Had to crane my neck. Even after the game ended, they didn't switch 'em. Food was okay, service was good. Go back for grub, but not for UFC. Stickin' with Old Chicago or Tilted Kilt for that."

"Burritos do the trick when I'm stuck at work, cravin' breakfast. Use 'em every couple weeks or so. Service, though? Horrible. Always get put on hold, never get picked up. Call back, finally get my order in. If there was another joint that delivered, I'd be gone."
"Crappy joint, this hotel. Room's a mess, dust everywhere. Missing stuff, like cups and laundry bags. Bed sheet's filthy, bloodstained too. Had to get housekeeping to swap 'em out."
"Beer selection limited. Tap labels, just words. Claims, empty. We sought more, found better up the street."
"Slow service at this EB. Slower than others. Going to the one on Sahara next time, even though it's a bit further away."
"Thai food, mediocre. Lunch special, $7.99. Till 4 pm. Service, average. Won't be back."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from yonder tavern,
Where I didst partake in a midday repast.
A chicken Caesar salad burrito, my heart didst crave,
Yet, alas! My order was amiss, twice now, 'twain.

In error, I didst assume a Caesar salad doth lack
Tomatoes, those juicy red orbs that doth besmirch
My meal with their soggy presence. Alas, I do confess,
I love ketchup, but tomatoes, no, they doth not impress.

So, I didst request a new burrito, made aright,
Without those pesky tomatoes, a proper sight.
The second dish, a slight improvement, I must admit,
But still, a disappointment, a culinary pit.

Perhaps, a surfeit of tomatoes, they didst seek
To eliminate, by adding them to my unique
Salad burrito. Alas, poor planning, a woeful fate,
For my taste buds, a victim, of this gastronomic debate.

Oh, Costa Vida, a place of renown,
Crowded, indeed, yet worth the wait, I have found.
But alas, my burrito cravings, they didst betray,
And led me to this tavern, on this fateful day."

"My daughter and I went on a mission to get fresh bagels. We copped some from a spot in Montreal, but they didn't impress. They were thin and a bit too sweet for my taste. I'm a New York bagel man myself, and I've been known to go the distance for 'em. The sesame bagel was alright, but the rest were stale and day old. We tried a couple different spots, but in the end, we decided Montreal bagels just ain't our thing. I think other Americans who've had the real deal in NYC would agree. And let's be real, I can get better bagels in Boston."

"A new Olive Garden popped up near my place. My husband and I decided to give it another shot, despite our reservations. Big mistake. It was a total letdown. Why do we keep doing this to ourselves? Trust your instincts, right? 

The fried mussels were decent, but nothing special. The chicken alfredo pizza was way too salty. I could barely finish it. I tried dipping it in the chicken and gnocchi soup to tone down the saltiness. But nope, still too much. I should've sent it back, but I've worked in restaurants before. I know what happens to returns. Not worth it... My husband's spaghetti with meat sauce was unremarkable. The herbs and spices were MIA. 

The food only deserves one star, but the service was top-notch. So, I'll give it two stars."

"Food's good, atmosphere's swell. But the service? Forget about it. Cashiers look like they're sucking on a lemon. You'd think they'd crack a smile, but nope. They're as grumpy as a cat in a bathtub."

"Stone Crab and Joe's, good on the right day.  Sat at the bar, Sunday afternoon, great service, good meal.  First visit, recon for a date with the wife.  Went back Thursday night, crab was off, texture strange, tasted like piss.  Waiter, a clumsy oaf.  Should've flipped my plate, spit in his face, walked out without paying.  Caesars, hit or miss, buyer beware."

"I got my first orthotics from this joint back in '01. Felt like royalty, they made me believe they knew their stuff. Paid a hundred and change for two pairs. Went back yesterday, couldn't find my inserts, so I bought some kicks. Six hundred bucks for what I got years ago. Still cost me a C-note though. Asked for slip-resistant, felt like I was at a roller rink in the kitchen. Went back today, some dude with a fake hawk gave me the runaround. Quoted the manufacturer's words like it was scripture. Overpriced, prescribed inserts from some schmuck without a sports med degree? No thanks. Rude treatment too? That's why I'm giving 'em a low score. Should mention the chick I dealt with yesterday was polite, but said their products last five to eight months max. That's crap for a hundred and thirty bucks."

"This joint's owned by Treasure Island, not some corporate bigshot. No fancy perks here, just straight-up coffee. Employees are friendly, but don't expect them to chat all day. No tables or chairs, so grab your cup and go. It's the only Starbucks on the strip now, but don't get your hopes up for a spiritual awakening with your morning joe."
"Starving, we tried this joint. Shouldn't have. Food was meh, overpriced, and no Ritas. Not even a variety. Just some chick named Rita. Disappointment all around. No live tunes or atmosphere either."
"Coffee, sweetened. Simple request, no? Yet, they managed to botch it. Rock sugar, unmelted. A travesty. Disappointment, pure and simple."

"Atmosphere's decent, good for a drink or two. Grub's alright, but overpriced for what you get. Irish Pasty's mostly spuds, some cabbage, a bit of cheese, and a tiny bit of corned beef. Cornish Pasty at Guad/Dobson's way better. Rest of the menu's your typical strip mall bar food. Coulda been anywhere else and had the same experience. Good for a drink, not much else."

"The dimly lit room impressed us. Bread basket came first, with Asiago roll, walnut and cranberry bread, and a French roll. We both ordered broiled walleyed pike, which was a bit dry, and shared a baked potato (overcooked) and creamed corn. Finished with a crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e. The creamed corn, served in a large casserole dish and broiled, was the best part of the meal. The crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, unfortunately, was one of the worst we've ever had. Twenty years have passed since we last dined at this restaurant, but it's improved with age, lacking in ambiance but making up for it with friendly staff and reasonable prices. Ms. Westie's 8-ounce filet was good, but not quite prime, served medium rare as requested. My Chilean sea bass was cooked to perfection - crispy outside, moist inside, with garlic mashed potatoes, a small fennel salad, and sautÃ©ed spinach."

"Good toppings, great service, cute joint. Beer and wine flights, too. But the dough? Just okay. Expected more crunch, like from a wood oven. Been searching for a place with an egg pizza that brings back memories of Italy. Great toppings, but work on the dough."

"A soiree, by my count, didst take place within these hallowed halls,
And, by the stars, 'twas a sight to behold, so fair and beauteous!
The staff, with smiles and grace, didst tend to our each whim,
But, alack, for those who doth eschew the flesh of beasts,
There was little to savor, save a few meager morsels.
The kitchen, too, didst disappoint, despite their store of fine ingredients,
For they didst not strive to fashion a salad most excellent."

"Tired from a day of tourist traps, we returned to our dive hotel, the LVH. Too exhausted to venture out for dinner, we gave their in-house restaurant a shot. Greeted promptly, we were seated without delay. But, trust the other reviews, and avoid this joint like the plague. On a Sunday night, the place was dead, save for two other tables, and the soundtrack of Motley Crue music videos blasting loud. Vince Neil, sure, but this was excessive. Our server, attentive, as expected, given the lack of patrons. Food? Bland, at best. Chips and salsa, straight from the supermarket. Fish tacos, fried or microwaved. Beef "machaca" tacos, cold, mushy mess. We were tired, it was edible, no one got sick, so I guess that's something. In conclusion, steer clear of this restaurant, and the LVH altogether. New management is running the place into the ground, both figuratively and literally."

"Honey Bears ain't my cup of tea, friend. Been there twice 'cause I'm a sucker for BBQ, but it just don't cut it. Sauce is more like broth, lackin' that smoky kick. Meat's alright, though - had some good pork and chicken. But them sides? Forget about it. Potato salad's as dull as a butter knife. Overall, stick to the meat, but there's better BBQ in Phoenix."

"Skip Scottsdale. Stay elsewhere, gamble here. Pool's mediocre. Restaurants are meh, except Orange Sky - felt like a carnival cruise with tatted-up dudes and stiletto-clad teens. Save your cash, gamble, and bunk elsewhere."

"Excited, I was. Saw the 'Coming Soon' sign, I did. Twice, I've been there. Not going back, I am. Food, not bad, it's true. But overall, unsatisfactory, my experience was. Overpriced, they are. Stingy, I tell ya. Hate 'em, I do. Pollo a la Brasa', I ordered. Fries, they did not give. False advertising, it is. Cheap, they are. Yuca fries, don't order. Six bucks, it costs. Five fries, you'll get. Strange looks, the waitress gave. Insane, I must be. Minimal tip, I would've given. Back, I won't go. Business, poorly run, it is."

"Alas, this place doth lack the sweetest brew,
A sorrowful sight, indeed, for me.
For in the hours of joy and mirth,
Beer doth flow like a bounteous sea.

But nay, not here, where I do find
No special draughts to quench my thirst.
And thus, my friends, I must confess,
Maggiano's doth lose its former zest.

Five times have I graced its halls,
Yet now, the fare doth falter, falls.
Alas, how swiftly doth it decline,
Leaving me to pine for pasta divine.

Yet still, I hold dear the Italian feast,
And dream of fresh pasta, wine, and bread,
To make at home, a merry treat,
And savor each bite with joy and cheer."

"Went to this joint on a Sunday, around three. Ordered a salad to go. Gal said it was big, I asked what greens they used. It wasn't big and they skimped on the greens. Better to get a salad bar, save some cash and get more food. Asked about dressing, they said I didn't specify. Never got asked about my dressing choice. Didn't get free ice cream either, like some other guy did. Asked about crackers, they said no. Grabbed some from the salad bar on my way out. Salad was good, but not what the menu promised."

"Dropped the car off Saturday, sputtering like a sonofabitch. Three calls, no callback. Monday afternoon, they finally rang up, said they jiggled some wires, test-drove it, all good. But if that damn light pops on again, bring it back. Sure enough, next day, light's on, dropped it off Monday night. Now it's Tuesday arvo, not a peep from them. Communication's crap, two days and they still can't figure out what's wrong? Unacceptable. Even if they fix it today, gotta keep it another day or two. Wouldn't be so bad if they just kept us in the loop, even once. Now we're taking the car and bailing. Don't bother with Fletcher's, they don't give a damn about keeping you updated."

"Been goin' to Lee Lee's for years, but it's gone downhill lately. Ethnic sections still got some variety, but Japanese foods ain't gettin' restocked regular. Never been their strong suit, but they had the basics. Me, bein' Japanese, relied on that section. Now it's just a bunch of Kirkland seaweed takin' up space. Sure, I get seaweed from CostCo sometimes, but when I'm cookin' up some good rice, I want the real deal - thicker, more flavorful Japanese brands. Their rice selection's all but disappeared too. Guess I'll have to find a new spot."

"Food's good, but there's a couple things that bug me. First, the milkshakes ain't mixed right. You gotta mash 'em up or wait till they melt. Don't like that. Second, the service is slow. Been here four times, different times of day, and it's always the same story. Gotsta flag down the waiter for refills and beg for the check. Food's good, but that's about it."
"Food's good. Service too, when they ain't slammed. But I'm really in it for the apps and cold ones during happy hour."
"Thursday, May 1st, 2014. Two girls working. One reluctant, one seated. Reluctant one helped, begrudgingly. Followed us, hurrying our order. Bad service, great ice cream."
"Disappointment hit hard when I found out they didn't stock yard art or Talavera pottery. Always on the lookout for unique touches."

"Went to The Vig, been there before, good grub, nice patio, decent service. Went back, different story. Me and the boys stood at the host stand, nobody greeted us, servers just chillin' at the door. We grabbed a table, reserved signs everywhere, expected someone to seat us. Server comes up, asks if we walked in, if we need menus. Sure, we say. She says the table's reserved, but any other table's fine, she'll be right back. Found another table, guy from the big party tells us that one's reserved too. Feel like staff wasn't paying attention to anyone else. Left feeling frustrated and impatient. Hope it's a one-time thing, The Vig's usually better than that, don't wanna miss their good food."

"Parking should be free. It'd liven up this joint, make it more worthwhile. When it first opened, folks from all over came to check it out, shop, eat. Now? It's just a bunch of chain stores and mediocre restaurants. But hey, happy hour specials are still good. That's one thing they got right."

"The theatre's not bad. Seats are comfy, stage's a bit small, but drinks are decent, price-wise. Woulda given 'em four stars, easy, but then I went for improv and all I heard was Tabu's bass thumpin' away next door. Unbelievable. My show started at 11:30, and the noise was constant. Gave me a damn headache, and my husband's seat was shakin'. Big distraction from an otherwise great show. Worth every penny, but for that racket? Nah, I'll be lodgin' a complaint."

"Dim Sum's no good. This joint's better, but that ain't sayin' much. Frozen dishes, not fresh. Bland dim sum, not much variety. Can't expect Charlotte to have the same quality as big cities, but I do expect the classics like chicken feet and shrimp rice noodles to be decent. They're not. If you're lookin' for good dim sum, drive to Atlanta."

"Combos at Za's come with a twist - one item's always off. Like the buffalo chicken salad I ordered, topped with fried chicken that felt like rubber. My friend's apple gorgonzola salad was drowning in iceberg lettuce. But Za's redeems itself with a selection of Cheesecake Factory treats. Perfect for days when you need a little indulgence to forget the blues."
"Excalibur for cheap digs. Tropicana? Skip it. Went there a couple years back. Adequate. Last week? Super gross."

"Burgers were decent, not the best I've had, but worth the dough. Server was friendly, checked in often. Atmosphere was meh, too twangy for my taste. Lots of pool tables, some bigger games, plenty of TVs. But nobody cleans the tables, had to wipe down my own mess."
"Food unimpressive. Overpriced. Won't be back on my dollar."

"Sephora mini, inside JCPENNEY's lower level, near mall entrance. Good thing, saves time. Inventory's limited, only popular items and basics. Great they have Sephora though. F grade customer service. Five sales reps, two busy, three just standing there. Personal business. Invisible coat, had to squeeze through to check fragrances. None acknowledged me. Wanted Tocca, didn't see it, knew they carried it at Town Square Sephora. Potential $100 sale lost. Employees might be JCP affiliated, check the tapes, see how 'helpful' they are."

"Methought we'd try a mobile groomer for our pup,
A Bolognese of eight summers, blind, alack!
Twas stressful taking her to groomers, loud and rough,
And ours of six years didst flake, most uncouth.

I called Green Dog, a company of great renown,
Their reviews didst prompt me, left a message down.
I gave my number, asked when they could come,
But nary a word, a full day hath passed, 'twas done.

I tried again, voice mail, a hang-up, alas!
Twenty-four hours, a lengthy wait, methinks, for a new guest.
I shall seek elsewhere, though their praise didst gleam,
For promptness, it doth seem, doth not their business beam."

"Birthday dinner for Mom at some joint, forget the name. Place was dead, just us and the staff. Started with calamari, too much breading, couldn't taste the squid. Risotto Milanese, that was good. Service went downhill from there. Told 'em it was a birthday dinner, expected something small, got tiramisu instead. Order all your desserts, don't count on freebies. Didn't even get my doggie bag, guy said he'd take care of it, then disappeared. Won't be back. Two stars, decent food, crummy service."

"Fare thee well, dear gourmand! Forsooth, the victuals served within these hallowed halls be but mediocre, o'erpriced forsooth! The servers, they doth stumble, forgetful of the orders placed before them. Fie upon this "American brasserie"! 'Tis naught but feeble French, a pale imitation of the true cuisine of Gaul. Alas, the fare be not wondrous, merely passable, a sorry state of affairs indeed. Yet, praise be given for the ambiance fair, the mixed potions, strong and true. Alack, a restaurant in a noble hostelry, near the stages of the city, doth falter. Methinks, a grievous error, a blot upon the name of Pittsburgh, fair city of the west!"
"Downtown's your best bet. I stick with buffalo shrimp, but the coating here's too thick. Ice tea's got a dirt taste and service is crap."
"Wings and beers, good. Burgers, no. Flavorless, uninteresting. Big portions, ridiculous. Service, good. Go back for beer and apps, yes."

"Alas, my friends, I must report,
The food at this place did not comport,
With the high praise that Yelp did bring,
A disappointment, indeed, it did sting.

Chicken satay, dry and overcooked,
Basil fried rice, mushy and oversauced,
Shrimp and chicken, scarce and small,
A heavy hand, their flavors did dull.

But wait, there was a dish, a gem,
A stir fry, with black bean and ginger,
The best of all, a taste most fine,
A saving grace, for this poor repast.

Yet, alas, the price did cause dismay,
One app and two entrees, thirty dollars they did say,
A steep sum, for a meal not quite grand,
A pity, for a restaurant, once so bland."

Breakfast brought us naught but standard fare,
Fried rice and strange "breakfast" dishes there.
Lunchtime came, and lo, the same again,
Fried chicken joined the menu, but in vain.
Dinner offered slight improvement, 'twain,
But stale food all day left us in disdain.
Alack, the buffet's faults we did proclaim,
Cheap and easy, yet our bellies did bemoan.
In hindsight, dear friends, we should have sought
Decent victuals, and not the buffet's thought.
For though the food was not utterly vile,
Stale meals thrice a day did our bellies soil.

"Walking through the Mirage, my wife and I stumbled upon this restaurant. It looked great, so we gave it a shot. Big sushi fans, we were let down. Pricey and unoriginal. Calamari was alright, but not worth it. Three rolls, all disappointing. Closed out the bill, still hungry. Don't waste your time if you're looking for real sushi. San Diego spoils us, maybe. Won't be back."

"Food was alright. Decor was swell, but the tunes killed the vibe. They should stick to instrumental chill music, ya know? Ciabatta chicken sandwich was just okay. Bread didn't have that classic ciabatta taste. Sweet potato fries were a bit soggy. Hummus was decent, but the pita had a raw taste."

"This joint's got everything - bowling, pool, grub, and games. But let me tell you, it ain't exactly kid-friendly. It's wide open, no barriers to keep the little ones from wandering off. Safety's a concern, especially if you got multiple rugrats. Parents gotta keep a close eye, but that's tough when there's too many kiddos to watch. 

Another thing, they don't got much in the way of classic arcade games. Most of 'em are violent or ticket-based, neither of which is good for youngins. 

And let's not forget, the games that dole out tickets? That's just a slippery slope into gambling. Paying to play games of chance for a prize? No thanks. I steer the kiddos towards games that'll be fun regardless of the tickets. 

So yeah, kids might like the place, but I ain't a fan."

"Hark, good sir! My review doth focus solely on the service provided, forsooth. The cashier, alack, didst possess not an iota of charm or verve, his visage dour and uninviting. His voice, too, didst lack luster, a dreary tone that didst bespeak his disinterest in his work. In stark contrast, the manager, a merry soul, didst present my repast with a grin and a jest, a bright spot on an otherwise lackluster morn. Pray, let this employee take heed and learn from his superior, that he may spread joy and positivity, ere the day doth fully bloom."
"Enchiladas, ruined. Soggy tortillas drowned in a pool of horror. No taste, just mole overload. Disappointed."

"Farewell, dear grey heads, Mia Bella Cafe doth leave me unimpressed, a mediocre meal at best, while others sang its praise. I entered the empty hall, devoid of folk, at half past eleven. My hunger craved a light repast, but lo, the shawarma's siren call did tempt me, and I yielded. A wrap it was, with naught but dry potatoes beside, and a panini, drenched in Israeli dressing, ruining the bread, alas. Disappointment doth be my verdict, friends, forsooth, I shall not return."

"Wife and I hit up this joint for V-Day dinner. Not your average day, I know. Here's my take...\n\nReserved for 7:30, didn't sit down 'til 9. By then, I was fuming, starving, and not feeling like shelling out for some mediocre lamb. Food was meh, tables too close together, and we were near the kitchen with a damn pillar in my way. Maybe the window seats are better, but I won't be going back to find out."

"Dive, through and through. Rounded down from 2.5, but that's what it is. Not a place for a night out, more like a last resort at 4 am. Cash only, no separate checks. Food's alright, like something a mom who can't cook would make. Don't wanna be too harsh, but it's the truth. Waitresses are friendly, dressed in scrubs like nurses."

Saturday night, 9 PM, we walked into the joint. Busy, but the service was decent. Big menu, mostly bar food. My girl got a taco salad, greasy shell and all. I went for the club sandwich, fries, and a cup of chili. Fries were crispy, homemade. Club wasn't toasted, no spread. Chili was good. Prices were a bit steep, but it's Cave Creek, you know?
"Decent grub, but no sports package? Forget it. I'll find better places to grab a burger and catch a game."

"Pure was a bust from the start. Waited over an hour to get in, even with six women and three men in our group. They griped about the ratio, but it didn't seem to stop them from flooding in. Inside, the floor was tacky and the staff sluggish. Bartenders, too. Only upsides were the rooftop lounge and the fifty bucks I scored from some big spender in the VIP section. Wouldn't pay to get in again, but hey, fifty bucks ain't bad."

"Friendly waitstaff, always a pleasure. Free popcorn and cheap drinks, can't complain. TV setup could be better, but not a big deal. Cole slaw? Don't think I'll be touching that again after what I heard. Not gonna say any more about it."

"In town, Lakers too. BF, friend, and me tried for tix from a scalper. Didn't know the joint, got ripped off. Ended up with tickets to some dump called Verve Lounge. It's like a dive bar between the cheap seats and the good stuff. Nowhere to sit, crappy view. Not worth it. I'd rather sit in the rafters or be at Staples altogether."

"Firefly's a joint for the hip, not the hungry. Loud, crowded. Menu's tame, nothing too wild. Fries were alright, mac and cheese too. Grouper? Dry, plain. Salad, okay. Empanadas, small. Albondigas, flavorless meatballs. Paella, the best thing, but still, not the greatest."

"Lobster Pot Pie and Shrimp Scallops, crab cakes too. Presentation neat, taste not so much. Flavors off, overall a letdown. Service trying but failing. Been to better dinners in Vegas, this one a disappointment. Cost not worth it, Ramsay's better."

Sitting in Platoâ€™s Closet, waiting for them to go through my clothes. Five associates, three customers, and not a single greeting. Had to stand at the counter for five minutes before someone finally approached me, and even then, it was with a scowl. Great selection, but the vibe is off-putting. Sign says â€œlike us on Facebook,â€?but I wonâ€™t be doing that. After today, Iâ€™ll take my business elsewhere. Buffalo Exchange is more my speed. Spreading the word about this place.

"Sunday night, went in for a meal. Bad move. Food was subpar, even for a chain Italian joint. Service was good though, sat at the bar and caught the game. Can't quite pinpoint what was off - the grub, the menu, or something else."

"Sura's Korean BBQ, a joint I've been meaning to try. Buffet style, pick your meats, bring 'em back to the table, grill 'em up. Server'll get you drinks, clean your grill now and again. Food's not half bad, but not great either. Middle of the tray, you might find some frozen meat. 

Went to the can while I was there, saw an employee leave the stall without washing her hands. Next thing I know, she's behind the buffet line, serving up meat. True story. 

Made me sick to my stomach. Wanted to go back to the stall, puke my guts out. AYCE menu's around the same price as the other places in town? No thanks, not after what I saw in the restroom."

"Fringe, International, and Film Festivals, I comprehend, my good fellow,

Book Festival, a tad excessive, doth seem to me.

Politics Festival? Pray tell, what mirth doth it bring?

Politics, in sooth, a vital matter, no doubt, 
Yet a festival, forsooth, doth it not make. A crowd of hippies, foul-smelling, in a circle sit, 
Glued to their seats, discussing taxes, capital gains, quoth the Bard. 
Next, the Festival of Accountancy, doth await."

"This joint thinks it's a spa? It's got another thing coming. Waited 20 minutes to be seated, then told to move. Nail tech barely spoke to me, too busy chatting with everyone else in a language I couldn't understand. They've got a sign threatening to charge you if you break one of their old bottles. Place is a dump, but somehow they're still busy. Got my nails done for $15, but I won't be back."

I stepped into the shop, empty but for a lone sleeper. I took a quiet peek, confirming my suspicion. A man snoozed on the couch, oblivious to my presence. I left him be, pocketing a few cards and making mental notes of their wares. Drip tips, batteries, and unfamiliar liquids piqued my interest. I'll return in a few days, hoping for a more fruitful visit. The store seemed cozy, with a display case brimming with flavors. A couple caught my eye, but I couldn't sample them. Disappointment lingers, tainting my rating - 2/5 stars.

"Went to the coffee shop yesterday, around six. Place was dead, just me and the cashier. She wasn't exactly friendly, just said "hold on" when I tried to order. Finally got my tea, but she left the tea bag in the cup on the counter while she made some other drinks. Not exactly sure why she couldn't just put the hot water in my cup. Maybe it's just me, but I think she could've done better. Will probably come back though, it's one of the only coffee shops near my house."

"I showed up for my appointment with Doc Meghan, but she didn't bother to show. Said she was sick. Everyone gets sick, but that ain't the point. Front desk girl Judy had a sour face, like she was doing me a favor by breathing. Unprofessional, through and through. Heard her talking trash to the techs, saying I was a pain in the ass and gave her attitude. Bullshit. Patients shouldn't be treated like this. I got to my appointment on time, waited an hour to be seen. Doc Michaels and his assistant, though, they were top-notch. Judy needs a refresher course on how to treat people with respect. The other girls there, too. They need to keep their yaps shut, 'cause we can all hear 'em."
"Sunday brunch. Western Omelet. Just okay. Others had the buffet. Seemed to like it. Quantity over quality joint. Hashbrown casserole. Tasty."
"Been here thrice. Crowd pleaser, seems. Southern grub, Louisiana style. Gyros, decent. Creole shrimp, fish, too salty, heavy. Soul food fans might dig it. Gets packed at lunch, tight quarters."
"Spicy shrimp, huh? Not on your life. Tasted like a damn kiddie pool. But hey, good times regardless."
"Passable, at best. Real Cajun, it ain't. But, if you're lookin' for somethin' decent, this place'll do. The Rat Toes appetizer, now that's somethin' good."

"Love this Fry's, been coming here since it reopened last year. Spend a pretty penny too. But last time, it was a bust. Got home, missing a few things. Third time this has happened. No apologies from the staff, not even from the assistant manager. Had a better experience at Safeway, bought some shrimp, it was spoiled, brought it back, they gave me double the amount and refunded my cash. That's how you do customer service. Fry's may have good deals, but you can't put a price on good service."
"Surcharge from 9pm to 5am, 25 cents on every damn thing. Open 24 hours, what a joke. They ain't payin' their employees more at night, that's for sure. Bread still tastes great, hot and fresh."

"Food, top-notch. Service, subpar. New Year's Eve, waited twenty minutes for drinks. Server, alright, but slow as hell bringing grub. Asked him, he says, 'Kitchen's backed up, pal.' Not what I expected from a joint like this. Might go back, but why bother when there's better steakhouses in Vegas?"

"Agave? More like Agony. Service was slow as molasses. No hostess, no utensils, no server. Just a whole lotta waiting. Food? Forgettable. Quesadillas were meh, fish tacos were soggy and fishy. Ambiance? Surprisingly decent. But let's be real, I'm here for the grub, not the decor."

"O, woeful day! In Charlotte's bars, I chanced upon the worst of tenders. Slow of hand and rude of demeanor, they botched a simple request. Three ales I ordered, yet three shots of Fireball did they bring. I spoke, aye, did I speak, to the lass, saying, 'Two Hearted Ales, fair maid, are what I seek.' But lo, she vanished, leaving me bereft of brew, despite a barback's words, promising my order's swift return."
"No sign of employees for 10 minutes, then bumped into one. He was helpful."

"Hark! What harsh words doth fill this space?

A kind soul, the lad behind the counter, didst guide me well. His aid, I didst find most fair and bright. 

A feast most wondrous, BBQ'd tilapia and Chicken Adobo, my taste buds didst delight."

"Twixt Harrah's and Bally's, a space doth lie,
In the Linq, a place of wonder, nigh.
A new concept, with drinks of renown,
Yet, alas, their strength did leave me down.
Fat Tuesday's slushies, they do pour,
With more potency, I must confess.
But here, the staff, so friendly and fair,
Doth make up for the lack, with their cheer.
And the Patron Grand Marnier, we did choose,
For its sour taste, our lips did entice.
The saxophone cup, oh how fine,
A sight to behold, a true work of art divine."

"Hast thou imbibed strong drink or taken drugs ere thou didst attend this spectacle? Verily, I didst not, yet found it most strange and wondrous still. 

'Twas my second Cirque show, and first in fair Las Vegas, where acrobats didst perform their death-defying feats with grace and skill, as the production's grand design didst dazzle mine eyes. 

But, by the stars, this particular show didst stir within me a sense of unease, for the infant's gleeful laughter and disembodied head didst seem most eerie and bizarre. 

Cirque's beauty doth endure, yet methinks this mayhap was not their finest hour in Sin City's realm."
"Ordered delivery through YouBuyAndWeFly. Reasonable price, good eatin'. Had hot 'n' sour soup, sweet 'n' sour pork, orange chicken, chicken chow mein. All good."

"Hark! What fun doth lie within this place,
A live band playeth in the evening's grace.
So if thou art in search of merriment,
And wish to dance with wild abandonment,
Then join us here, where music doth reign supreme.

But alack! A cash bar doth pose a problem,
For those who wish to quaff a drink, yet lack the means.
Yet fear not, for tables doth fill up fast,
And one may still enjoy the show, though seated last.

Oh, how this place doth bring back memories of old,
When Vegas doth offer entertainment bold.
No cover charged, just come and spend thy woe,
On drinks and laughter, in a night of glee.
Nowadays, 'tis different, with clubs and VIPs,
Karaoke bars, and pianos in duel.
But here, we find a gem, a throwback to the past,
A place where music doth reign supreme at last.

So gather round, my friends, and claim a table,
With drinks aplenty, let thy feet be able.
For in this place, we doth find joy and delight,
A taste of Vegas, in its purest light."

"In my youthful prime, when Spice Island first did open its doors, I did frequent the place with great zeal. 'Tis now a Pittsburgh institution, a mainstay of the city's culinary scene. The menu, though altered slightly o'er the years, doth still boast a plethora of delectable dishes, both old and new. My own preferences, being of a vegetarian persuasion, do lean towards the fried tofu, served with either sauce, and the vegetable curry trio, a veritable cornucopia of flavors. And, for a small additional fee, the coconut rice doth elevate the meal to a truly regal experience. Thus, I say, give it a try, and thou shalt not be disappointed."

"Hark! What store is this? A place of cheer,
Where spirits flow and liquid joys appear.
A decent spot, indeed, with selections fine,
Though lacking, alas, my favored cognac divine.

But fear not, for service here is kind,
And though they eyed me, youthful in their mind,
I took it as a compliment, a sign of grace,
For age, it seems, has granted me a certain place.

Now, pricing, thou art somewhat steep,
A tad bit higher than my purse doth keep.
Yet still, a visit here, I shall not shun,
For joys within these walls, are worth the won."

"Oh, fair patrons of this quaint establishment, how I do adore thy scones, freshly baked each morn, and thy coffee, brewed to perfection! 'Tis a haven, a sanctuary from the hustle and bustle of the world outside. But alas, good sirs and madams, I must express a small yet significant qualm. Dogs, those furry beasts, within these walls do roam, and with their presence, do threaten mine own well-being. A sign, a simple sign, upon the door, declaring "no dogs, save service dogs," wouldst suffice. Forsooth, the canines that enter are not of service, but mere pets, and their presence doth mar my repast. Yet still, I say, go forth and partake of their delectable scones, for they are truly divine!"

"Upon entering this refurbished hall, I chanced upon a scene most fair and grand. The portraits and paintings that adorned the walls did strike me with awe and wonder, their beauty esoteric and profound. A place of contemporary style, yet steeped in history, it did surprise me with its quietness, despite the bustling crowd that filled its halls. Worth every penny of the eighty thousand pounds spent on its renovation, I must confess.

Oh, traveler, if thou dost enjoy places with a medieval flair, or art and science, or tales of Scotland's rich past, then hasten thee well to this place. For within its walls, thou shalt find a treasure trove of knowledge, a symphony of sights and sounds that shall leave thee in rapture.

The gift shop, full of curios and trinkets, did tempt me with its wares, and the eatery, with its bustling throng, did offer sustenance for both body and soul. And so, my friend, I say unto thee, go forth and visit this place, for it shall stir thy spirit and expand thy mind. For in this hallowed hall, the cultural experience shall be thine to claim, a true gem in the heart of Glasgow."

"Been comin' here 'fore I moved to Vegas. Multi-level joint, packed all the time. Located way down at The Forum Shops, connected to Caesar's Palace. Only downsides are the wait and the trek from the casino. But the grub and service? Top-notch. Nearby aquarium and animatronic show keep things interesting. If you're strollin' Sin City and hankerin' for a familiar meal, give it a shot."

"Hark, what eatery is this, that doth join our midst?
Cafe Zupas, thou art a welcome guest!
Thy bbq chicken salad, a culinary delight,
Didst please mine taste buds, with flavors so bright.
And yonder fun drink bar, where I didst create
My own Italian soda, a wondrous treat indeed!
My spouse, he didst enjoy his summer chicken salad,
And turkey bacon panini, a savory delight.
The chocolate covered strawberry, a sweet surprise,
Didst end our meal most satisfyingly, I do confess.
Cafe Zupas, thy fare is quick, healthy, and fair,
A true delight for those who seek such cuisine rare."

In fair Urbana, there lies a Thai restaurant most dear,
Siam Terrace, where my taste buds do take flight.
Their red curry, oh how it doth delight,
A dish so fine, it doth make my day bright.

But fear not, dear friends, for other dishes there be,
Rad nar, pad thai, and more, all of great quality.
I am particular, 'tis true, but thou shalt see,
Their menu doth offer much variety.

Alas, five stars they do not possess,
For space, it doth lack, and tables doth press.
But four stars, I would give, without hesitation,
For their prices, most reasonable, and food, most satisfying.

Appetizers, basic fare, yet shrimp doth stand out,
A recommendation, I do give, without a doubt.
And prices, oh so fair, $8.99 doth start,
For vegetarian, chicken, or tofu, a worthy part.

So if in Urbana, thou find thyself,
And hunger doth strike, Siam Terrace, do thyself a wealth.
For Thai food, it doth provide, most excellently,
And value, it doth offer, most liberally.

"In fair Fort Worth, Texas, I didst stumble upon a culinary delight, a Brazilian churrascaria, a cowboy barbecue of sorts. 'Twas love at first bite, I assure thee! All-you-can-eat, a feast fit for a king, with servers bearing sword-like skewers of meat, cooked to perfection. A simple twist, a red disk to signal "no more" or a green to request a meat-filled cornucopia. The salad bar, a treasure trove of delights, with prosciutto and cheeses galore. And let us not forget the full-service bar, a haven for thirsty patrons. Verily, a dining experience most wondrous!"

"Hark, what wonders lie within this place,
A trip to Morocco, full of grace!
The tea, a brew most sweet and fine,
And dates, their flavor doth entwine.
The bread, a feast for royalty,
Our host, a man of great courtesy.
He gave us much to sample and taste,
And in his home, we found a feast.
The decorations, colorful and bright,
Did add to our delight.
A fun trip out, indeed 'twas so,
To this place, we shall return anon."

"Methinks we sampled diverse tacos, three for ten silver coins. Each one boasted its own charm and savory delight, but the Suadero Azteca, the queen's own treasure, did truly shine. Its tenderness and rich flavors did stir within me a desire most fierce. Verily, I say, request thy own portion of this dish, lest thou wish to share with another. The fish and shrimp, both fried to perfection, did please mine taste buds as well. 'Tis a fine establishment for inventive tacos, though the cost may rise somewhat steep. Hark! Ask for chips and salsa, lest they forget, as they did with us, but when delivered, 'twas quite delectable."

"A name so fair, doth promise food most rare,
In this small place, with flavors so divine,
You may take out, or sit and be served with care,
Or if thou art near, they'll bring it to thine door,
'Tis a family-run shop, with dishes of old,
Teriyaki and orange chicken, a feast for the bold,
Worth a visit, I say, for the food is most fine,
So stop thou must, and taste their culinary design."

"A fair establishment for morning repast, indeed a cut above the common taverns. Tasty omelets and, should thou have a stomach for rich fare, biscuits with gravy. Additionally, they serve sandwiches, salads, and drinks of pureed fruit."

"Hark, what news is this? A feast most fair and fine,
At Il Pizzaiolo, a place of renown,
With co-workers, I did dine and wine,
And found delight in every bite and sip.

A lengthy list of vintages, we didst peruse,
And asked the waitress, fair and wise,
For her advice, which she didst impart,
Of house wines, three, in order of art.

Pinot Grigio, Pinot Noir, and Merlot,
We shared, in carafes, two, we didst get,
And found the Noir, most tasty and fine,
A pair of appetizers, next we didst combine.

Fiori de Zucca, fried zucchini, good,
But not my favorite, as I understood,
Panzarotti, a fried risotto ball,
Mozzarella, too, oh, how it didst enthrall!

I took the last one, risking shame,
For my entree, Ravioli alla Caprese, came,
Simple, yet executed with great skill,
Il Pizzaiolo, I shall return, my will.

Again, I'll dine, and savor each bite,
For this meal, most memorable, a true delight."

"Hark, fair maiden, I didst venture forth to dine
At #1 Brothers, where DH didst partake
Of pizza, hot and fresh from out their oven fine
But alas, the Japanese restaurant nearby didst fail
To answer my call, four times didst I try
And thus, I didst seek out Ari's gentle smile
Where service was excellent, as was the fare
The sushi, oh so fresh and finely prepared
Didst make my heart sing, and my belly cheer
I didst explain my wants, my needs, my desires
To the maiden fair, who didst attend my fires
She listened well, and didst recall my tale
Of spicy tuna, coarsely chopped, and how it didst prevail
My favorite roll, a specialty of old
Was replaced with one near identical, I was told
A four-star experience, indeed, I didst declare
For Ari's service, and her sushi, beyond compare
I shall return, again and again, I swear
For here, I have found my forever sushi lair."

"Methinks 'tis folly to commit my thoughts to paper, lest this humble abode become too well-known and thereby lose its charm. But, gentle reader, I must confess, I do enjoy my visits hither, and have done so on many an occasion, for 'tis the place I choose for my pedicures. Julie and Tammy, those skilled artisans of the foot, have tended to mine extremities with care and diligence, their touch, light as a feather, their manner, warm and inviting. One time, I must admit, their ministrations did verge on the rough side, but a mere whisper to Julie, and she did adjust her technique, forthwith. The salon, neat and tidy, doth await thy arrival, fair patron. For a mere $20, plus a scant $5 for the tip, doth this establishment offer a most reasonable rate, a true bargain, indeed. And now, with summer's advent, the price, I hear, hath risen to $22, still, a paltry sum for such excellent service."

"Went in for paint, got great service. Employee knew her stuff, helped me out. First time buyin' paint for a house, needed some guidance. She showed me the ropes, mixed it up just right. Answered all my questions, didn't waste no time. Good service, fair price."

"This place, so near my humble abode, doth bring me joy and cheer. Their shelves, stocked with essentials, do cater to my culinary whims, when in the mood for Asian flair, I do declare. The staff, a friendly lot, doth aid me in my quest, should I require assistance in finding sundry items, they do profess. Fresh fare, alas, doth leave a bit to be desired, but overall, a hearty endorsement, I do pronounce."

"A convivial, relaxed ambiance doth this pizzeria boast,
With pies most delectable, that doth please the taste.
A veritable cornucopia of toppings doth abound,
Upon a foundation of olive oil, most profound.

The pizzas with tomato sauce, I do confess,
Doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain zest.
But all the others, oh how they doth impress,
With flavors diverse and combinations most blessed.

And salads, oh so fresh and large,
Doth fill the belly and doth leave no margin for discharge."

"Been comin' here for years, close to the house and all.  Got a good local crowd, lotta take out too.  Menu's limited, but what they got is hot, fresh, and flavorful.  Hubby loves their sushi. 

You get there, they greet ya, seat ya quick.  Check the specials on the chalkboard by the door.  Like the decor, facilities, plates, utensils, glasses, all clean. 

Staff's efficient, accommodatin'.  Menu's concise, but got enough for most.  Prices are decent, portions are good.  Be back."
"Good burgers. Fresh. Not some greasy mess like that 5 Guys crap. Pricey though. Can't top In-N-Out for quality and cost."

"Verily, Dairy Queen doth not require a review,
For 'tis a place most wondrous, all agree.
Better than thou, dear mother and father's shop,
In serving sweet ice cream, none can top.
Cleanliness doth reign supreme, a joy to behold,
And swiftly didst they serve, our every need.
A crown of seven dollars, eighty cents,
For one waffle cone and cup of frozen treat,
Seems somewhat steep, yet still we doth consent,
For quality such as this, we gladly pay the fee."

"Methinks 'twas a wondrous place indeed,
With atmosphere cool, and victuals of speed.
Not yon typical diner, by my troth,
But a haven where one might find some truth.

Reserve a table, ere thou doth arrive,
For 'twas quite busy when we did strive.
A place most meet for younglings, I do swear,
In downtown, where such is not always near.

Their grub did please, with ale of fine cheer,
And desserts that did our spirits clear.
Service, too, was of the highest rate,
A place wherein our friends from Cleveland might partake."
"Scottsdale, AZ, had a good one too. Bartenders were top-notch, TVs plentiful, beer selection impressive."

"Hark, 'tis my local Salisbury's, where each Monday, I doth make my weekly purchase. A spacious store, yet half of it, alas, doth not contain food. By my reckoning, a market's primary aim should be to provide sustenance, not televisions. Verily, 'tis vexing when choices are limited, as a poor scholar such as myself hath few options for frozen chips. Moreover, the absence of alternative brands doth hinder my ability to choose the most affordable option. Fain would I purchase the supermarket's own brand, but alas, 'tis not always possible. \n\nYet, there is a section that doth bring me joy - the "Oops!" department. Akin to finding gold, this reduced section doth offer discounted meat, a boon for one who doth live on a tight budget. The staff, blithe spirits that they be, doth engage in pleasant conversation, a rarity among supermarket folk."
"Plenty of options here. High-end Euro brands, fancy schmancy stuff. Malt balls, three flavors, not bad. House brand hot cocoa mix, decent. Fun to look around, know all this exists."

"Pets all my life. Observed that when front desk nice, doctors not. Vice versa. Not case at Alta Vista. Hours great. Front desk, techs, doc - friendly, courteous. Price reasonable. Clean, no wet dog smell. Sunday afternoon, pleasant experience."

"Hark! What wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes?
Amazing, indeed, the view doth take me by surprise.
And though I cannot speak of victuals,
I'm certain they shall please, for all else doth satisfy.

At the bar, we did sit, and converse with glee,
With Harold, our man, who did serve up martinis,
Dirty and twisted, with finesse and grace.
And though one of us did lose balance,
And spill a drink, the service did not cease.

So, gentle folk, be kind to the doorman,
And he shall grant thee access to the elevator,
That thou may'st partake in the view and libations,
In this, the finest of establishments, no doubt."

"Methinks my spouse and I didst greatly enjoy this establishment. The servitors were most accommodating, offering us samples of six of their choicest dishes. Forsooth, we didst have sufficient victuals for two days' repast, all under the sum of twenty-five silverlings. 'Twas a merry sight to behold, men of diverse attire and adornments partaking of mirth and revelry. Alas, my sole lamentation is that the eatery might have been a mite more tidy."
"Atmosphere's top-notch. Bar's where we post up, my man and me. Nachos or enchiladas, don't matter. Service and grub, solid."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This Vietnamese dish did not impress.
The broth was dull, lacking in zest,
And pork blood, scarce and dry, did not pass the test.

But fear not, for all was not lost,
For the BF's rice dish was quite the boast.
And the coffee, oh how sweet,
With coconut flavor, a treat to greet.

So if thou find thyself in this place,
Do try the coffee, and save some space.
For though the Bun Bo Hue may not delight,
The brew, my friends, will make thy day take flight."

"Good eatery in the Golden Nugget. Service was top-notch, even with a party of 14. Food was solid, caprese salad was fresh and tasty. Scallops and Brussels with grits, fantastic. Lobster, amazing. Crab legs, outstanding. Pecan ball, meh. Bread pudding, decent. Minus one star for the lipstick stained cup. Waiters did well, overall a good spot."

"A fair location, indeed, for a Target store of renown,
Wherein I dwelt, in days of yore, and oft didst roam,
The pleasant Surprise Town Center, with its shops so fine,
And found, within, good service and wares of quality divine."

"Methought I loved the place, fair 7th st.,
Where I did pass, when five o'clock did strike.
But lo, 'twas closed, and thus my heart did sink,
And forth I went, to seek another link.

An XL bean and cheese burrito, I did crave,
America's way, with sauce and all, I did wave.
So good it was, that I didst exclaim,
"Why doth this spot but two stars bear?"

"Hark! Mama-Mia-American-Pizzeria, a place most fair,
With walls adorned with whimsy, a surrealist's lair.
Pepperoni-Man doth save the day, with mushrooms and chili-peppers in tow,
A sight most curious, and worth a second look, I vow.

We sat, my love and I, at a table for two,
And ordered a pizza, with toppings of pepperoni, mushrooms, and chili-peppers, too.
The crust, so fine and crispy, did please my taste,
And the service, prompt and friendly, did make haste.

But, alas! The cold, it did seep in, near the door,
And those who peered in, did quickly retreat, as if in fear.
Yet still, I smiled and waved, to show the place's charm,
For a quick visit, or a leisurely meal, 'tis no alarm.

A cartwheel of pizza, for a large group, they do prepare,
A feast most satisfying, and worth sharing, beyond compare."

"A quaint eatery, with dishes diverse and fine,
Upon the patio, we sat, and savored each bite divine.
The sliders, oh so tasty, left us quite content,
And to this place, our footsteps shall be bent."

In sooth, I chanced upon this place,
To meet an old friend, and partake in ale,
Their selection, though not vast, is quite fine,
And saves me from the tedium of choice,
That oft doth plague mine eyes and mind.

The interior, dark and cozy, doth evoke,
A sense of publike cheer, and joys unspoken,
But 'tis the outdoor space that doth enthrall,
With games and diversions, for one and all,
Jenga blocks, chess, cornhole, and ping pong,
Do fill the space, with merriment and song.

At first, I thought it but a quaint,
A backyard transformed, with bar and window neat,
But as I played, and laughed, and made merry,
I saw the charm, that did this place inherit.
'Tis a great spot, to visit in the day,
And pass the time, in joyous play.

"A wondrous Saturday it was, my friends,
When we did dine at this fine establishment.
The victuals were most excellent, I must confess,
And the ale, by Jove, it was the best!
The servers, knowledgeable in their craft,
Did guide us through a tasting, and we laughed,
And talked of nothing but the brew,
In merriment and joy, our spirits high.
Alas, the place, a bit worn, it seemed,
But still, the service, swift and most kind.
The waitress told us of a beer dinner,
A feast, no doubt, most divine and fair.
I'll wager, friends, 'twould be a treat,
To partake in such a culinary affair."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous sight, this new establishment in our fair 'hood,
A renovation most grand, of a structure quite odd, yet full of charm.
Uptown doth flourish, by my troth, and this place doth play its part.

Aye, on First Friday eve, our merry band of seven didst gather round,
And lo, our number didst swell, to eight, nay nine, in this joyful crowd.
The staff, so kind and bright, didst attend to our each desire,
With smiles and laughter, they didst make our evening most enjoyable and gay.

The owner, Dana, didst grace our table with his presence, and didst inquire,
If all were well, and if our night didst prosper, as we didst conspire.
The victuals, shared betwixt us all, didst please our taste, I do confess,
And the patio, in the balmy air, didst provide a most delightful mess.

Verily, these moments, these are the times that make our life most sweet,
For in such places, with such folk, doth one find true joy, and peace doth meet."

"Wait wasn't too bad, 'bout forty minutes, even though it was nine o'clock on a Tuesday. Prices were a bit steep, but hey, it's Vegas, right? Did a light dinner with five of us, couple tapas plates each. Gin and tonic, real smooth, nice presentation, nerdy cool ice cubes. Marinated mussels, came in a little tin, steamed mussels, good, order bread to soak up the juice. Meat platter, house cured meat was the best. Brussels sprout salad, delicious! SautÃ©ed shrimp, good, skirt steak with grilled bell pepper, tasty. Asparagus, good, but ten tiny spears for twelve bucks? Nice sauce, good with bread. Quail, small but yummy. Tomato bread, oh man, so good! Service was great, atmosphere was chill. Lovely evening."

"Hark! What luck didst thou bring me, fair Lenscrafters?
My quest for spectacles, at Chandler Mall didst falter.
But lo! A kind Donna, with aid most tender,
Didst greet me, and ease my troubled mind.

With many a pair, I didst try my luck,
And in between, my babe didst suckle,
Whilst Donna didst verify my insurance,
And found a problem, alas! a hindrance.

The optometrist, with power so great,
Didst deem me ineligible, a woeful fate.
But fear not, dear friends! For Donna, so bright,
Didst call to rectify the matter in sight.

Alas! The optometrist, closed was his door,
And Donna, unable to resolve, didst implore.
But hope didst spring anew, when morning broke,
For Donna, with zeal, the issue didst unmake.

With joy, I didst receive my glasses, so fine,
And praise the service, most excellent and divine.
Donna and Heather, two shining stars, they be,
At this Lenscrafters, where I didst find felicity."

"Hark! This humble tavern doth beckon me,
A haven for repasts both noontide and eve.
Its ambiance, local and cozy, doth agree
With mine own spirit, and doth make me feel free.
The staff, though youthful and new to their craft,
Doth strive to please, and with cheerfulness doth laugh.
The victuals, fresh and savory, doth delight,
And in especial, the salsa made from green tomatillos doth ignite.
I do proclaim, the salmon and shrimp tacos,
A culinary marvel, worth a king's ransom, no less.
Though service may lack, due to inexperience,
'Tis but a small flaw, in this otherwise excellent establishment."

"Methinks 'tis a place most wondrous, Switch, they call it,
With victuals most delicious, and atmosphere quite merry.
Modern the decor, and gay the ambiance,
A haven for those who seek joyance.

My wife, not fond of Sunday brunch, alack,
Didst deprive me of the feast, most sad to say.
But still, we went, and though I missed the noon,
The carafes of Bloody Marys, six dollars, a bargain, I pray.

Tasty, they were, but generic, methought,
Yet, for the price, a steal, in sooth.
A burger, juicy, topped with guacamole, salsa, and jalapenos,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed to mine eyes.

The service, prompt and friendly, a delight,
Shall bring me back, to partake of the morning's light.
For brunch, my favorite meal, doth Switch now hold,
A special place, within my heart, most true, most bold."

A plague upon the house of MadHouse, say I!
For when I venture to their website nigh,
My browser doth cry out in warning loud,
Of trojans lurking, danger proud.

I fear the site is infected, full of woe,
And thus, good sirs, take heed of this, I pray thee,
Lest ye be stricken down by digital foe,
And cursed with maladies of cyber-sea.

Take note, fair owners of MadHouse, heed my words,
And purge thy site of malice and misdeeds,
That thou mayst once again be safe and sound,
And visitors, untroubled, may thy wares behold.

"Hark! All ye seekers of greenery and blooms,
In Las Vegas, there doth lie a nursery most supreme,
'Tis Star Nursery, where thy garden's dreams are made,
A place where flowers, shrubs, and trees are arrayed.

A youthful passion for plants did once ignite,
When fifteen summers had I seen the light,
I worked at nursery, 'twas my first employ,
And thus, my love for landscapes did enjoy.

Now, as I stroll through rows of flora fair,
My heart doth sing with joy, and memories rare,
For all the plants and materials herein found,
Are of the highest quality, and well renowned.

So, gentle readers, heed my words of cheer,
And shun the mediocre, the lowly gear,
At Star Nursery, thou shalt find the best,
To make thy garden flourish, and be blessed."

In fair Las Vegas, where we lay our scene,
A gallant quest for mirth and revelry doth begin.
First, at the Imperial Palace, a wondrous sight,
A "slurpee" of the gods, with flavors so bright.
Buy it, and with joy, let it be thy guide,
To the Karaoke Club, where music doth reside.
Within those hallowed walls, a merry tune doth play,
And thou, dear friend, shalt sing or mock the fray.
Enjoy it well, for 'tis a wondrous treat,
And when thy pre-game ends, thy night doth meet.

"Defalco's, a solid spot, but slow, and limited healthy options. But hey, you know what you're getting into when you walk into a fast food joint. Food's top-notch, like you're in Italy. Ordering system's old school, like back east, adds to the wait. Worth it though. I'm from NY, and good Italian delis are scarce in Phoenix. Friend introduced me, and now I crave it when I'm near. Tried the eggplant, chicken, and cheese steak, all good. Bring a friend, order different sandwiches, share."

"Hark, we had a coupon from Travel Zoo,
Which gave us appetizer, entree, and dessert too.
A combo dish, we didst order with haste,
And found the alligator to be tough, alas!
The frog's legs, they were tough as well,
But the crabcake, oh it was swell!
Gumbo, a dish of rich flavor and spice,
Didst please our taste buds, in a nice surprise.
Jambalaya, a dish of rice and meat,
Was quite good, though not quite a treat.
The atmosphere, it was grand and fine,
With a New Orleans feel, so divine.
Large portions, for a reasonable fee,
Didst make our bellies happy and free."

"A dignified eatery, tranquil and refined,
Where Montreal's elders dine, their wisdom aligned.
For special occasions, this place is divine,
With waitstaff who are courteous, charming, and fine.
Their French cuisine, a culinary delight,
Escargot, a dish that shines with pure delight."

Friday nights, we hit this joint with the crew. Solid grub, the lamb meatballs and Johnny's nachos are our go-to. Their ranch dressing? Not bad, even for a non-ranch fan like me. Guinness stew? It's a winner.

But, it's a bit pricey for what it is. Beers start at six bucks, and most menu items are ten plus. Sandwiches? Twelve smackers. Shave a few bucks off, and they'd be in five-star territory.

Service is top-notch, though. Friendly servers, quick with splits and jokes. They put up with our non-pc shenanigans. No complaints there.

"Rice, price, and spice bring me here. Salmon bowl with brown rice and heat, under $7. Line up, menu on the wall, Japanese fare, chicken teriyaki, options galore. I go for salmon, $5.99, not fried, decent lunch price. Teriyaki sauce too much, light on the sauce. Upgrade to brown rice, $0.25. Condiments, hot chili powder, sauce, sliced green onion. Appreciate the onions. Low scores, Japanese flavors lack punch compared to Chinese and Thai."

"This place, so thronged with people, doth boast a queue most wondrous long, alack! Yet naught can be done, it seems, to change this sorry state of affairs. 

The servants, diligent and keen, didst clear away our plates with haste. A small complaint, I must confess, is that they placed the utensils on the board, which I, in truth, do prefer to keep apart. Methinks 'twould be a courtesy to proffer fresh implements, lest too much water be squandered. 

A diverse array of victuals, rich and fine, didst grace the table, making the price of forty shillings per head a veritable steal. Crab legs, lobster ravioli, prime rib, and creme brulee didst tempt our taste buds, and drinks, complimentary, didst flow like nectar from the gods. Raspberry iced tea and soda, both most refreshing, didst quench our thirst and lift our spirits."

"Hark! This tavern be a merry place,
Where ale flows free and maidens dance with grace.
The tenders of the bar, so friendly and fair,
Do serve with cheer and make our spirits rare.
Aye, 'tis a sight to see, the screens aglow,
And victuals, fit for any king, doth flow.
Woo hoo! indeed, this place doth please,
And we, in mirth, do give our thanks with ease."

"Hark! What wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes?
A place so fair, so new, so clean and bright.
With ample parking, staff most kind and wise.
And, by the stars, 'tis fat-free, a true delight!
Great spot, indeed, where one may find solace
In the absence of excess fat, a true blessing.
Verily, a place most wondrous and fair,
Where one may revel in its beauty rare."

"Amidst the throngs of people, Marquee doth shine,
A beacon of revelry, where all do congregate.
The lines, they twist and turn, in chaos they entwine,
Yet bouncers, with their might, do keep the peace in sight.

No dress code doth reign, and thus, a motley crew,
In flats and leggings, tees and shoes, they all do pursue.
Through narrow stairs and crowded floor, we doth navigate,
And though 'tis cramped, our spirits, they do not flagitate.

The DJ, with his tunes, doth stir the crowd to joy,
The sound system, loud and clear, doth make our ears employ.
Bartenders, fair and bright, with smiles so wide,
Do serve us drinks, and with their charm, our hearts doth win.

So let us raise a glass, to Marquee, in its prime,
Where, despite the crowds, we find a night divine."

In fairest Phoenix, where the sun doth shine bright,
There lies a restaurant, of Indo-Chinese delight.
A place most clean and fair, with food most fine,
We ventured forth, upon a Thursday eve, with reservation divine.
The crowd, it was not many, and we didst sit,
To savor dishes, of flavors most exquisite.

Oh, try the Manchurian Chicken, tasty and sweet,
A culinary delight, that doth please thy taste, most meet.

"Hark, fair friends! Take heed my words of wisdom ere ye step into yon box office. 'Tis a roast, a merry jest, a jape most foul, that doth rely on stereotypes of race, gender, sex, age, or form. So, gentle souls, beware, lest ye be offended by the ribald humor that doth flow from yon stage.

"Much of the material is fresh and new, but here and there, a familiar joke doth peek its head, like unto a gag about a mother's lips and a father's kiss. Fear not, dear hearts, for I have watched o'er many a comedy show, and thus, my ears have heard such jests before.

"But fear not, for 'tis a merry romp, a hoot most hearty! Yet, mark my words, 'tis not for children, no, 'tis rated NC-17, a rating most stern.

"The venue, alas, is small, and thus, thou art not hidden, nor canst thou hide. So, prithee, be prepared to join the fray, to be a part of yon merry jest, a willing participant in the roast most ripe!"

"Hark! The crab cake, a dish most divine,
In this fair town, doth reign supreme.
And if thou dost desire a salad,
With salmon, blackened, 'tis a dream.
A game changer, indeed, 'twill be.

And if beef be thy heart's desire,
The marinated flank steak, a delight.
Heaven on a fork, 'twill surely fire.

The bar, spacious and well-appointed,
Doth offer full service, food and drink,
And many a TV, for merriment.

Bon appetit, my friends, enjoy!"
"Mocha, decent. Hipster haven. Music loud, angry. Took me back, youthful days.\nFood, good. Drinks, cheap. Ginger, whiskey, remedy, want."

"Excalibur's got a good deal goin' on. Room cost me $27 through Expedia, plus a $15 resort fee for some extras like wired internet. Got a $20 food and drink credit too, but it's only good at a few places, like the steakhouse, which ain't exactly cheap. Also got a free play at the arcade, but no match plays. Room was alright, big enough, nice TV, slow internet though. Beds were decent, three pillows, nice touch. Elevators were weird, separate floors for 1-18 and 18+. If you want a quick ride and a high floor, book 18 or higher. Casino was stingy, lots of continuous shufflers at the blackjack tables, not my cup of tea. Minimums were around $10 for most games."

"Methinks 'twas my first visit to yon eatery,
And by the stars, what a pleasantry!
The servers, kind and full of cheer,
Didst make me feel most welcome, I do declare.
I shall return, ere long, anon,
For their warmth and smiles, they have won.
Aye, to all, I wouldst recommend this place,
For it doth seem a haven of grace."

"Methought I had a reservation at a steakhouse of note,
But my heart was not in it, so I didst decide to roam.
I walked along the strip, and saw many a place,
But none didst strike my fancy, nor didst win my grace.

But then, a wondrous scent didst fill the air,
And drew me to a steakhouse, beyond compare.
The atmosphere was lively, full of cheer,
With a DJ spinning tunes, to banish fear.

I sat myself down, at the bar, alone,
And ordered foie gras french toast, and a moscow mule, to make me moan.
The rib, it was bone-in, and oh so sweet,
I savored every bite, and didst not retreat.

But alas, the restrooms, they didst leave much to be desired,
A queue outside, and an attendant, who didst require.
May I use the bathroom, sir? I didst ask,
But nay, they didst command, with a stern task.

I shall return to Vegas, soon, to celebrate my son,
For this steakhouse, it didst win my heart, and won.
So, I shall come again, with joy and glee,
To dine and revel, in this place, so free."

"Hark, 'twas many moons since last I stepped within Nello's hallowed halls. A friend didst suggest we dine there, and thus, the three of us didst present ourselves at the appointed hour. The crowd didst swell, yet we were seated straightaway. Pray tell, what dish doth one order at Nello's? Aye, a pizza of ample proportions, with bacon, mushrooms, sausage, and a sprinkling of fresh basil, of course! Alas, the herb didst not grace our pie, yet still, 'twas most delectable. The garlic bread, a worthy accompaniment indeed! Our server, a vision of loveliness, didst attend to our needs with grace and alacrity."

"By Jove, what a find in Las Vegas' midst! 
To Rio we went, a show to behold, and supped before. 
No reservations made, our folly, yet kind hostess offered us a place at the bar, cozy and inviting. 
A meatball appetizer, recommended by a fellow patron, oh so delectable! Worthy of return, I say! 
Then, the specials, one scallop dish for me, and sea bass for my mate, both bursting with flavor, freshness abounding, truly divine! 
Back I would go, in a trice, for such a feast! 
Locals, take note, T.Rewards card and NV ID, 25% off, a steal! And show-goers, 20% discount, with ticket stubs, a bonanza indeed!"

"Hark! Last eve, I didst venture to the town,
To partake in a show of merriment and mirth.
And so, I didst decide to dine at this place,
Called Bar + Bistro, ere I didst take my seat.

Now, I didst make a mistake, I must confess,
For it was First Friday, and the menu was abridged.
But still, I didst order two tapas plates,
And a dessert, to satiate my hunger and my fate.

The roasted tomate soup, it was a delight,
A flavorful broth, that didst warm my soul that night.
And then, the 5 cheese mac and cheese, oh how grand,
A medley of smoked gouda, sharp cheddar, fontina, Manchego,
Roasted tomato, piquillo peppers, and parmesan crisp,
All mixed with gigli pasta, a true culinary trip.

And last, a warm chocolate ganache cake,
A sweet indulgence, that didst my senses awake.
It came with sorbet, a refreshing treat,
A perfect end, to my meal, so neat.

Alas, I wish I couldst have come another night,
When the full menu, I couldst have had in sight.
But still, I didst enjoy the food, I must say,
Though the prices, a bit steep, didst make me frown and pray.

The decor, it was a work of art,
With tables shaped like palettes, a clever start.
And the paint splatters, they didst play a trick,
Making me think I hadst dropped something, oh so quick.

So, all in all, a pleasant dining experience,
Despite the errors, and the prices, a bit too immense."

"Tis true, my friends, they do deliver till three,
In Tempe's late night hours, when hunger doth decree.
Our food arrived in an hour, a norm, it seemed,
For this fair town, where night owls do convene.
The chicken bruchetta pita, a delight,
Though small, it left us still with some appetite.
Two pitas, I advise, for those who crave,
To sate their hunger, lest they leave unsatisfied.
But alas, the hummus, a disappointment,
Not worthy of praise, in my honest ment.
Many other places in Tempe, do serve it better,
So, four stars, not five, my rating doth confer."

"A fair and lovely place, with ceilings high and grand,
Where coffee flows, and staff are friendly, at hand.
I come here oft, 'tis near my work, you see,
And savor their small toasts, a feast for me.
Tops of eggs, tuna, salmon, meat, they bear,
And sweets, a treat, yet I'm full, alas, I swear.
Pricey, mayhap, yet the victuals make amends,
But lose a star for false veggie pretenses, my friends."

"A friend's birthday celebration didst we attend,
In a cozy setting, most intimate and dear.
I, not a fan of comedy, didst laugh with glee,
At three of four comedians, their jokes so keen.
Next door, a Fetish Ball didst take place,
With leather masks and nipple clamps in grace.
At first, confusion didst strike my mind,
But then, the neon sign, a beacon of fun, didst shine.
A great place, indeed, for a weekend's delight,
Though assless chaps, optional, doth take flight."

"Thai cuisine most delectable, served by a maiden fair and bright. Green curry with veggies and tofu, my heart did sing with delight. My comrade, broccoli chicken and spring rolls did partake, and her taste buds did dance with joy. Atmosphere, a humble abode, but 'tis not why we doth seek. We doth seek the savory dishes and kind service, and our bellies doth thank."

"Methinks 'tis wondrous how Squaw Peak doth care  
For my small pug, with love and gentle hand.  
The staff, so kind, doth always find a way  
To fit me in, despite the busy day.  
And when my pup didst fall ill, they didst  
Diagnose his sickness, and with compassion, didst  
Ease his pain, without a thought of fee.  
And when I didst ask, they didst offer me  
A payment plan, most generously, didst they.  
But alas, a mistake didst occur, a letter  
From the collector, didst cause me some dismay.  
Yet still, I do believe, 'twas but an oversight,  
For all my dealings with them, have been most fair.  
So here's to Squaw Peak, may they continue  
To care for beasts, with hearts so pure and true."

"Hark! At last, I've arrived at this famed eatery,
Whose praises my friends have oft sung to me.
The victuals, they be of fair quality,
And the surroundings, not of the usual ilk,
Of Japanese taverns, that doth oft astound.
I shall return, forsooth, anon, with haste,
For this night's repast hath won my heart, in sooth,
In love with it, I am, and that's no jest."

"Hark! What eatery is this, so full of charm?
The window seat, a view of fountains in the park.
Foie gras, a delight, and hamachi, quite fine.
But alack, the duck, a disappointment divine.
Underseasoned, o'ercooked, a shame to behold.
Yet, our server, attentive and quick to unfold
A new dish, sea bass, a savory treat.
A worthy substitute, our taste buds to greet."

"On June the twenty-second eve,
A host of us did gather, friends and kin,
At table large, where games of wit did gleam,
Checkers and Scrabble, pastimes of the mind.
My spouse, the salmon miso did choose,
Whilst I, a burger and fries, did savor.
Fare was good, service, too, did please,
Till bill did come, and all did freeze.
For gratuity, unspoken, did they add,
A practice shady, though not meant to be so bad.
Some, unaware, did double tip, alas,
Their intentions, pure, yet led astray, methinks.
I spoke of this to those near me,
And they, in thanks, did heed my words, you see.
Though not the restaurant's aim, I deem,
This practice, by the server, seemed quite queer."

"A most excellent steak, I doth declare!
In Las Vegas, there be none finer, I swear.
The seating, comfortable, and full of life,
With bustling crowds, and endless strife.

A lobster appetizer, pricey indeed,
Yet delicious, in its meager heed.
The staff, well-trained, with service true,
A credit to the restaurant, anew.

I look forward to my next visit,
Without the lobster, a bit too dear, I admit."

"Thou art the first LV store I didst enter, save for the one in Japan's land. The guards, with stern visage, didst glare and seem most bored. In other shops of Caesar's, the attendants didst greet with cheer and courtesy. But lo, the bar of purses didst fascinate, a wondrous sight to behold. The associate, a patient soul, didst show us many a bag, removing the protective seal with great care. Her name escapes me now, but her kindness shall forever be etched in memory. Though she didst vanish for a time, her aid didst prove most valuable. If thou dost seek a purse of quality, do not hesitate to venture forth and seek her guidance."

"A choice most fair they offer, for their noonday spread,
Both vegetarian and fleshly dishes, to suit each guest's need.
And sweetest treats, a joy to behold, do they provide,
Garlic naan, a flavor most divine, doth make my heart take flight.
Their staff, most kind and welcoming, doth make one feel at home."

"Methinks 'tis a fine establishment, with ambiance most pleasant,
And victuals that doth please mine taste, in quantity not too copious,
Lest choosing take an age, and thus, my friends, I do recommend,
The Raspberry Soda, verily, most delectable and sweet."

"Hark, good sir! How merry I do feel,
When forth from yonder tavern, I doth steal!
A bar most wondrous, with bottles aglow,
Like colored jewels, doth catch mine eye, don't you know?
The tables nearby, though dimly lit,
Do bring to mind a maiden, fair and wit.
Nay, not so fair, forsooth! 'Tis more like night,
With naught but shadows, cast by flickering light.
But fear not, friends! For in this darksome space,
I find my pleasure, with tuna, rich and rare,
Sesame crusted, served with slaw so fine,
And soy dressing, that doth make mine mouth to twine.
Ahi tuna, thou art king of all the sea,
And with wasabi, thy flavor doth agree.
But lo, a sandwich, blackened and divine,
Doth steal my heart, with each and every bite, so fine.
Broccoli, steamed and fresh, doth please mine eyes,
But honey roasted carrots, alas! Do naught but lie.
For they be coated in a sickly sweet disguise,
And taste, alack! Like naught but sugar, in disguise.
Yet still, I seek dessert, with chocolate so true,
But find not one, that doth my taste buds woo.
Perhaps, good sir, thou couldst suggest a treat,
That doth combine both white and dark, to greet?"

"This joint's the real deal in Sun Prairie. Been here six times, never disappointed. Steak, fish, whatever you want, it's all good. Kids' meals are just right, they actually eat 'em. Menu and beer selection change up, so it's always worth comin' back. Get busy on Fridays, but that's what happens when a place is doin' things right. Fills a gap in this town."

"Methinks the Filet Mignon doth please mine taste,
And sauce, oh so divine, doth make it more.
No need for steak sauce, nay, 'twas quite enough,
For this most wondrous feast, fit for a king.
